results.title: The Champion = Battling Charlie [SILENT]
results.creator_credit: Essanay Film Manufacturing Company, Griffiths Short Films and Charles Chaplin
results.brief_description: The Champion, Chaplin’s third film for Essanay, is easily one of the funniest and is his most advanced film to date in plotting and characterisation. We meet Charlie and his bulldog sharing a hot dog. As they pass a gymnasium advertising for sparring partners, Charlie finds a lucky horseshoe and decides to give sparring a go, putting the horseshoe into his left boxing glove. Obviously Charlie has a special advantage and eventually wins his way through to the big championship fight against Champ (Bud Jamison). Along the way the beautiful daughter of the Gym owner,(Edna Purviance) is attracted to Charlie and likewise Charlie is interested in her. The hilarious slapstick prizefight is pretty even at first but when Charlie appears to be getting the worst of it, his bulldog springs to the rescue.

results.title: The Chameleon
results.creator_credit: Boulton-Hawker Films and Films of Africa
results.brief_description: A detailed study of the chameleon, film in its natural habitat in Rhodesia. General and close-up shots illustrate the animal’s appearance and movements, details of feet and eye movements, colour changes of the skin in response to light and temperament. Normal and slow-motion photography shows the action of the tongue in catching insect food. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: The Challenge of water
results.creator_credit: Australian Commonwealth Film Unit, John Martin-Jones and Joe Scully
results.brief_description: The challenge of Australia’s water resources - a problem, as good rainfall suited to agriculture occurs only in coastal regions. Describes government schemes for irrigation, hydro-electricity, reservoirs and other sources of water, including artesian bores. Indicates the widespread research which has made possible a better understanding of our climate today; includes work on evaporation control, artificial rain-making and sea-water utilisation.

results.title: The Challenge of survival: chemicals
results.creator_credit: Dick Young Productions, EPCOT Educational Media and Paul Gerber
results.brief_description: Shows how advances in agricultural research have increased our crop yields but have at the same time created a serious threat to our natural resources. Illustrates how our current use of chemicals has led to the poisoning of the environment and resistance developed amongst some pests. Examines alternative methods of pest management. Narrated by Michael Kane.

results.title: The Challenge of leadership
results.brief_description: Illustrates how leadership arises naturally in a critical situation. Helps supervisor identify and discuss the qualities that make a leader and the skills used in applying leadership by voluntary consent of the group.

results.title: The Challenge of change
results.brief_description: This video with accompanying trainer’s manual sets out to provide participants undertaking the training program with the knowledge and skills which will enable them to fully understand the impact, both positive and negative, of significant change in their work situation and how this impact may affect their interpersonal relationships both at work and in their family and social life.

results.title: The Challenge
results.creator_credit: British Information Services and Rentokil Film Unit
results.brief_description: Describes the history of the origin of the rat. Discusses the methods used to avoid rat infestation, whilst also describing the rats’ habits, and habitation. Essentially a propaganda film for the company Rentokil.

results.title: The Challenge
results.creator_credit: Australian Commonwealth Film Unit, Gil Brealey and John Carter
results.brief_description: This film deals with a situation in which one man is promoted over an another who has more experience in the same area. The man overlooked displays his resentment by insisting that nothing has changed and that he will continue to behave as he has always done. The question posed concerns the preservation of old relationships after promotion while making it clear that one is now boss. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: The Challenge
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture and Tony Doogood
results.brief_description: The factors which have contributed to Victoria’s progress: wheat and sheep; agricultural experiments; mining; dam-building and hydro-electric power; irrigation combatting erosion; bringing infertile land into production. The strength of Victoria’s economy lies in increasing food production.
